content: Hi @Josh Triplett @pnkfelix I was a little off the grid due to the current situation, but that got better for me. Shall we have a kick-off meeting at some time during the next 2 weeks? I'm fine with just chat and would prepare a short list of topics beforehand.
Any preferred doc host?
Hi @Florian Gilcher
by doc host, do you mean for logging internal discussions, e.g. hackmd.io ? Or do you mean for broader distribution amongst the rustc developers?
@pnkfelix yes, something like hackmd, dropbox paper
Okay. I can use anything. I suppose I have a slight preference for hackmd, but i will admit that dropbox paper has some advantages (like its comment annotation system)
I'm very much in the same camp (also with being able to use everything), so hackmd, unless @Josh Triplett has a preference.
So, there are advantages and disadvantages to several.
I'm not a big fan of Dropbox Paper. I tend to prefer hackmd for anything where markdown output is needed, or Google Docs for anything where markdown output is not needed.
That said, there's one other major downside to hackmd:
It's hard to find anything.
I find it incredibly hard to track down documents within hackmd, unless I have an external link for them.
If we're linking to documents via Zulip, then that should work fine. :)
I'm a heavy user of it, and usually, we take a master document and link off there, which works quite well.
If we want to have a folder of documents, or any kind of organization whatsoever besides "that doc I linked to in such-and-such Zulip thread", I tend to prefer Google Drive for that. :)
@Florian Gilcher That can work, as long as we always include the links into the top-level document.
Just, easy for things to get lost that way. But if we do it systematically from the beginning that seems fine.
In any case...the other question is scheduling for a kick-off meeting.
Doodle?
Yep, doodle would be great. You are based in PST?
I'll create a doc to start from and a doodle tomorrow morning. (put it into my calendar already)
I cannot remember if you are aware @Florian Gilcher , but I am now based in EST rather than CET
Yeah, I'm in US/Pacific.
(It's 1:52pm right now.)
@pnkfelix I was indeed not, thanks!
I'm writing a document later, I hurt my finger, so only light keyboard use :D
(not badly)
https://hackmd.io/r0QBWkvMSae43pfxNdTf6A
I have a notepad document here

Doodle for the first meeting is here: https://doodle.com/poll/bnpnr8g6sdhf3yqx and can also be found in the document. I opted for the approach of having a limited number of days this week and posting a new doodle if we can't find a date.
/cc @pnkfelix @Josh Triplett
Will fill out later today.
I've filled out the Doodle, but it doesn't look like there are any other entries on it.
So I'm assuming at a minimum that the meeting is not happening on Wednesday?
@Josh Triplett yeah, wednesday is probably off by now
ping @pnkfelix

(I don’t think the issue number approach is a popular practice; but if we are willing to have our notes linked from that very public space, then it could work in this instance, since we have a github issue already for this topic)

Regarding master documents: I tend to like to have those linked from Zulip topic titles, which in turn often leads me to use github issues, of all things, as the landing site, since then the (short) issue number suffices to make the link
I’ll go fill out the doodle now
OK, it looks like Wednesday may actually be a good time after all.
I'm certainly up for meeting today, despite the short notice.
@pnkfelix that's a good point.
I picked Friday, 7:30 pm local. Sorry that I wasn't available last night, I left work early and closed the laptop for good ;)
I'll watch for the calendar invite.
@Florian Gilcher 7:30pm which time zone, sorry? I'm trying to figure out when that meeting is going to be so I can schedule another meeting and not have it conflict.
@Josh Triplett local, berlin
Sorry, I kind of missed this notification and sent out the invite a bit late :/
ugh, that's now.
Ah, didn't see the invite.
@Josh Triplett Felix and me went ahead with the meeting, but made not decisions,. I'll send a summary later today.
...at what time?

Here comes the summary. For reference: https://hackmd.io/r0QBWkvMSae43pfxNdTf6A?both

We discussed some workflow things. As much as possible, outside of meeting notes, we'd like to keep it to Zulip+gh issues, if that's fine by you.

We've identified three main topics:

  • Fixing known issues and better documentation (mostly rewriting the copyright file)
  • Help to Rust developers and teams to improve the licensing situation
  • Help to Rust users to comply with Rust licensing, through better documentation

The linked document has a number of GH issues currently open.

Felix and I tried to find a number of good issues to start working with:
1) bringing https://paper.dropbox.com/doc/rustc-licensing-guidelines--Ao~xMyRsp7cmHLrQtvQPS_eQAg-13Vo9fltFmrsNrFpddiMA over the finishing line. GH issue: https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team/issues/220. This document does not need to be perfect and substantial parts are written.
2) Checking out the rustc_apfloat issues currently: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/55993. This issue is a bit annoying, as the license of upstream has moved, and we're unclear about the current situation, that might be an issue where @Josh Triplett detailed license experience might help.
3) https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-builtins/issues/319 is a tiny issue that can be worked through. We have someone at hand for a cleanroom implementation, if needed.

We did come up, but not nominate:

  • We need some categorisation of issues, such as "impacts compiler" or "impacts users", graded by severity.
  • compiler-builtins declares the wrong license: https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-builtins/issues/307 (this is a bit bigger, but a good one to work through later)
  • Licensing help for users.
    * This has design space, especially around automation
  • Rewrite COPYRIGHT file
    * This is a huge task, not good as a starter task
  • Work through https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/63232#issuecomment-517918295
    * This needs some planning on which to tackle first, but is also a good "next" task

There's two questions for @Josh Triplett that we had in the meeting:

  • What if a upstream library was relicensed after our port, but the relicensing is favourable to us? What's a good strategic approach.
    * This applies to ap_float.
  • If an MIT library is linked, does the binary need to be shipped with the library information?
It's 3:33am right now, but I'd be happy to go through those questions later this week. :)
No rush, please :D
